newsitem.title: INDIA: INDIAN HEADLINE STOCKS-factors to watch - Aug 28.
newsitem.headline: INDIAN HEADLINE STOCKS-factors to watch - Aug 28.

text.p: Following are some of the main factors affecting Indian stock markets on Wednesday morning.
NEWS OUTLOOK:
** Market holiday on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and other regional bourses but the Bombay-based National Stock Exchange (NSE) will remain open

** Finance Minister P. Chidambaram indicates he will announce measures to woo small investors to stock markets when he replies to the ongoing budget debate in parliament, the Business Standard newspaper reports

** The National Securities Depository Ltd (NSDL) approves fee structure that it will charge participants for its services. NSDL Chairman C.B. Bhave tells Times of India newspaper Indian firms IDBI, Reliance Industries, State Bank of India, ICICI, HDFC and ACC will be part of the first group of shares to kick off the system on October 31.
** Market regulator the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) likely to release an amended takeover code for companies later today.
Economic Times says SEBI has decided to allow open market purchases by acquirers during the period of an open offer to existing shareholders of a target company

** An ongoing investigation against former communications minister Sukh Ram will hit the forthcoming issue of telecom giant VSNL, the Times of India reports. If VSNL fails to launch its issue in September -- the only month with no major international issue set -- it faces the threat of being eclipsed by other issuers until the end of 1996, the paper says.
MARKETS:
** On Tuesday, the 30-share Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) index .BSESN rose 5.25 points to 3438.80
** The 100-share National index .NATEX gained 4.93 points to 1566.73
** The 50-stock National Stock Exchange index .NSEI ended 6 points higher at 1015 with net traded value at 7.78 billion rupees
** The 500-share CRISIL rose 0.66 points to 687.32
STOCKS TO WATCH:
** Blue chip cement firm Gujarat Ambuja says its 1995/96 net rises 47 percent to 1,478.2 million rupees
** Procter & Gamble says its 1995/96 sales rise to 3,663 million rupees, up 37 percent from the year ago
** Cement giant ACC expected to announce first quarter 1996/97 results at its annual shareholders meeting later today
** Half year earnings from engineering firm Wartsil Diesel expected today
** Countrywide tax raid on Shaw Wallace, the Business Standard reports
